subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Unicode Status
msgSnippet: IMHO Shavian and Quikscript (QS) are two different alphabets. There are a few common letters but there are also big differences. Those differences are
messageBody:
IMHO Shavian and Quikscript (QS) are two different alphabets.
There are a few common letters but there are also big differences. Those
differences are sometimes bigger than the ones you can find between the
Latin, Greek and Cyrillic alphabets.
More, there are some letters in Shavian which don’t exist in QS and
letters in QS which don’t exist in Shavian.
A text in QS written with a Shavian font would be barely readable to a
QS user not used to Shavian. Θατ’δ λοοκ λικε Γρεεκ το με.
A text in Shavian written with a Junior QS font would be barely readable
to a Shavian user not used to QS.
A text in Shavian written with a Senior QS font would be completely
unreadable to a Shavian user not used to QS.
And finally, why are there separate mailing lists for Shavian and QS?
Isn’t that because their respective users feel their script is different?

A few notes to Michael Everson about the document
http://f1.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/UD5rUZz8Ii7IZ4S-01rS0CnLaZ1s4UEMWsHTUS-5KuasKxzfC_w0gqV2DveiT3_Pa4AN_aNXBaIHYhfRkjELGwogzkyq83K8/Unicode%20Proposal/shavian-quikscript-draft2.pdf
The s-like glyph you used for mime in the QS column doesn’t exist. In
Shavian, it is more slanted, and in QS, another glyph is used.
The ƨ-like glyph you used for nun in the QS column doesn’t exist. In
Shavian, it is more slanted, and in QS, another glyph is used.
The character you used for up in the QS column doesn’t exist. This is
the first time I’ve ever seen it. It looks like a turned alternate form
of QS utter.
For the air letter, in the QS column, you used the QS letters out and
roe. You should use eight instead of out.
For the err letter, in the QS column, you used the QS letters eight and
roe. You should use utter instead of eight.
In the IPA column, I see “ɛr”. Shouldn’t it be “ɜːr”?

Such a strong unification of Shavian and QS, which I feel somewhat
artificial, would prevent us from mixing Shavian and QS text in the same
plain text document.
However, if that’s the way the proposal evolves, could you describe the
use of variation selectors in the standard?
Here is a complete list of the sequences I feel necessary:

peep VS1: Shavian form
peep VS2: QS form
peep VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
peep VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter

tot VS1: Shavian form
tot VS2: QS form
tot VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
tot VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter
tot VS2 VS4 ZWJ: QS form, half letter, links to the following letter
ZWJ tot VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter, links to the preceding letter,
such as in the word “out”

kick VS1: Shavian form
kick VS2: QS form (The QS form is more slanted)

fee VS1: Shavian form
fee VS2: QS form

thigh VS1: Shavian form
thigh VS2: QS form

so: no VS required

sure: no VS required

church: no VS required

yea VS1: Shavian form
yea VS2: QS form
yea VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
yea VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter

hung: no VS required

bib VS1: Shavian form
bib VS2: QS form

dead VS1: Shavian form
dead VS2: QS form
dead VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
dead VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter

gag VS1: Shavian form
gag VS2: QS form

vow VS1: Shavian form
vow VS2: QS form

they VS1: Shavian form
they VS2: QS form
they VS2 VS3: QS form, base form
they VS2 VS4: QS form, alternate form

zoo VS1: Shavian form
zoo VS2: QS form
zoo VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
zoo VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter

measure VS1: Shavian form
measure VS2: QS form

judge: no VS required

woe VS1: Shavian form
woe VS2: QS form
woe VS2 VS3: QS form, full letter
woe VS2 VS4: QS form, half letter

ha-ha: no VS required, Shavian letter only

loll: no VS required, Shavian letter only

mime: no VS required, Shavian letter only

if: no VS required

egg: no VS required

ash: no VS required

ado VS1: Shavian form
ado VS2: QS form
ado VS2 VS3: QS form, base form
ado VS2 VS4: QS form, alternate form

on: no VS required

wool VS1: Shavian form
wool VS2: QS form

out VS1: Shavian form
out VS2: QS form

ah VS1: Shavian form
ah VS2: QS form

roar: no VS required

nun: no VS required, Shavian letter only

eat VS1: Shavian form
eat VS2: QS form

age VS1: Shavian form
age VS2: QS form

ice VS1: Shavian form
ice VS2: QS form

up: no VS required, Shavian letter only

oak VS1: Shavian form
oak VS2: QS form

ooze VS1: Shavian form
ooze VS2: QS form

oil VS1: Shavian form
oil VS2: QS form

awe VS1: Shavian form
awe VS2: QS form

are: no VS required, Shavian letter only

or: no VS required, Shavian letter only

air: no VS required, Shavian letter only

err: no VS required, Shavian letter only

array: no VS required, Shavian letter only

ear: no VS required, Shavian letter only

ian: no VS required, Shavian letter only

yew: no VS required, Shavian letter only

he: no VS1/VS2 required, QS letter only
he VS3: QS form, full letter
he VS4: QS form, half letter

why: no VS1/VS2 required, QS letter only
why VS3: QS form, full letter
why VS4: QS form, half letter

may: no VS required, QS letter only

no: no VS1/VS2 required, QS letter only
no VS2 VS3: QS form, base form
no VS2 VS4: QS form, alternate form

low: no VS required, QS letter only

llan: no VS required, QS letter only

loch: no VS required, QS letter only

excite: no VS required, QS letter only

exam: no VS required, QS letter only

JF
